R: @robertwb 

I'm thinking harder about Robert's comment. It does seem like most transforms are explicitly verbs, though I do not think this has ever been documented.

And there are plenty of exceptions, like `Values`.

Short summary: I'm okay with this change, but it may just be better to update the Javadoc. Either way, may be worth discussing on the Beam list.
Either way, the JavaDoc for Distinct/RemoveDuplicates needs to be updated. It should talk about taking the `PCollection` and creating a distinct list of elements in it.
@dhalperi ,  let me start a topic on it. Thank you. :)
@eljefe6a  thank you.I'll add it to the javadoc in my next commit.

Fixed up the tests, rebased, and merged. Unfortunately, I did not see a way to smoothly migrate splittable `DoFn`, given its dependence on unsupported features. I have made notes about ways forward for it on [BEAM-801](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-801).
Thanks @dhalperi! I'll keep an eye to see that this actually solved the problem since it's hard to reproduce in a local environment.
LGTM. Interesting findbugs issue.
You'll need all subclasses to also guarantee it is `@NonNull`.

Interesting. FWIW all mac builds currently fail immediately without this PR. The script does not seems to have adequate output. I don't want to spend time improving it, instead preferring #1165 as the best way forward.

Can you add tests for the registrar? You can see the examples for [FlinkRunner](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/flink/runner/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/runners/flink/FlinkRunnerRegistrarTest.java), [SparkRunner](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/SparkRunnerRegistrarTest.java), and [DataflowRunner](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/google-cloud-dataflow-java/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/runners/dataflow/DataflowPipelineRegistrarTest.java).

The registrar could also be validated by changing the [pom.xml settings here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/apex-runner/runners/apex/pom.xml#L186) to refer to the runner by short name `TestApexRunner`.
Rebased & squashed now that #1161 is merged.
Yeah, reverted the change to make fraction consumed non-null. Don't love this inheritance, but I was not intending to make a backwards-incompatible change in this PR.

Minor Checkstyle error.

```
[ERROR] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify@2/sdks/java/core/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/options/ValueProviderUtilsTest.java:33:10: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier]
Audit done.
[INFO] There is 1 error reported by Checkstyle 6.19 with beam/checkstyle.xml ruleset.
[ERROR] src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/options/ValueProviderUtilsTest.java:[33,10] (modifier) RedundantModifier: Redundant 'static' modifier.
```

Checkstyle has been updated since the commit at which you originally based the PR, perhaps?
Argh, fixing test now.
LGTM. You are definitely correct.
I'd believe that.  Fixed.
Fixed.

This is still not very deterministic, because there are no triggers involved, so if execution is slow elements might not end-up in the same microbatch, or the job will finish before reading all.
Yet another great reason to keep going forward with triggers & accumulation modes.
For now, I'll giving more time on read from Kafka.

blocked on https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1160
I will ping this thread once that PR is merged.

LGTM.

Do we know why? I don't remember doing this myself.

CC: @lukecwik @peihe 

From Luke:

> The problem with the previous version was that our archetypes were not being maintained, and it was incorrect to say that they were compatible across those ranges because of all the backwards incompatible changes

This is completely true, and the process of fixing it manually in master works. But this does not help the release process, which is specifically designed to use `mvn release` to do all updating of versions repository-wide.

LGTM for master but it doesn't solve my problem with the `0.3.0-incubating` release because the plugin does all the version juggling between `0.3.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT` and `0.3.0-incubating`. I could try working around that manually but I feel that a proper fix would be good there.

On a side note, it's somewhat strange that the release plugin pushes everything to git right-away without giving me a chance to correct things. (I know that this is documented in the release guide and I knew it when executing the command, but still...)
Spark tests pass now, it's `Maven Archetypes :: Starter` that is broken (I think it's resolved in master now), I won't rebase again for now as I expect some comments for this PR.

R: @dhalperi.
It's best to test this PR branch by letting Jenkins run ROS on it.

Ported from #1143 to break it down a bit.
R: @bjchambers / @lukecwik / @tgroh or any other committer that I don't usually bother 😉

Totally agree that automatic pushes are not a great idea. There's a manual flag to disable them. It would be great if all this went through pull requests, but that appears to be non-standard. I'm hopeful we can improve this in the near future.
PTAL - I addressed the issues you pointed out.

At the same time, manual fixup of PRs is not reproducible across different committers or releases... a platonic release process would be fully automated. We ought to fix the process such that even if done in PRs we are not needing to do anything but rubber stamp; and we would catch breakages to the release process earlier. Maybe we can do some of this with the nightlies, like testing that we can run mvn release:prepare and that it compiles?
Thanks @kennknowles , @lukecwik --merged.

LGTM if/when Jenkins is green. Nicely readable.
LGTM. My one comment was actually independent of this PR.
Since Ben approved these, and you are now a committer, go ahead and merge.
I was mistaken about this being costly, but I am seeing a number of weird failures that look like flakes. I think perhaps our classpath setup is nondeterministic?
Feel free to leave this review lower priority and I will port a bunch more `DirectRunner` tests tonight.

I'd love to remove this script and have appropriate coverage in Jenkins.

I don't believe, however, this is the cause of the flakiness. This is something that runs locally only, without outside calls. So, my feeling is that this change removes coverage without giving much (any?) benefit.

Perhaps we should try to solve the problem differently by enhancing the precommit coverage in Jenkins, and simplify Travis just to be a quick and simple signal, primarily as a backup from Jenkins.
LGTM. Great! (please self merge).

Starting from this PR, WindowedWordCount post-commit test (streaming only) took double time than before (from 4.5mins to 10mins). It also slow down DirectRunner in pre-commit.

see: https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PostCommit_MavenVerify/1621/org.apache.beam$beam-examples-java/testReport/org.apache.beam.examples/WindowedWordCountIT/

LGTM.

Just checking -- do you see this as a job property, or worker pool property? If former, great. Otherwise, it could go to the worker pool options.
Thank you.

Hey, mea culpa on this one. We already have a `.travis/settings.xml` in our repo that we instruct Travis to use. Yet we had commands that were referencing the dead server (you can see it in the logs) so I think it is just needing to add `--settings .travis/settings.xml` to other maven commands, or using an alias. My solution here is far less readable and maintainable.

The integration test failures are now fixed. Please do review.

Note on Travis failure: on OSX, a bug in the Travis configuration (my fault) always causes failure. On Linux, the unresolved dependency (also caused by bug in Travis configuration) will cause failure in `test_wordcount.sh` until a snapshot is published. Note that actual building does not fail.
